net.jakubholy.dbunitexpress
Class EmbeddedDbTester

java.lang.Object
  net.jakubholy.dbunitexpress.EmbeddedDbTester
All Implemented Interfaces:
org.dbunit.IDatabaseTester
Direct Known Subclasses:
EmbeddedDbTesterRule
public class EmbeddedDbTester
extends Object
implements org.dbunit.IDatabaseTester

The core class for unit tests that need to access a database, by default an embedded (Derby) database, as simply as possible. It relies on DbUnit to do most of the work, including reloading the database with the test date before each test.

You will want to use this class if you prefer not to subclass the AbstractEmbeddedDbTestCase, for instance if using Junit 4. Under JUnit 4 you may actually prefer to use EmbeddedDbTesterRule instead of this because it calls onSetup() automatically, see the example in its JavaDoc.

The class uses an embedded Derby DB for test data. The necessary tables must be already created - you may achieve that by creating a DDL file DatabaseCreator.DDL_FILE_PATH (normally testData/create_db_content.ddl) and either executing DatabaseCreator.main(String[]) or calling DatabaseCreator.createAndInitializeTestDb(). The database is expected to be in ./testData/testDB/ (a path relative to the folder where your unit tests are executed from), which will be taken care of if you use the DatabaseCreator to create the DB from a DDL.

If you want to load data from another file than the default one, you can either use setDataSet(IDataSet) or override createDefaultDataSet().

The added value of this class is that it's pre-configured to interact with an embedded Derby database and the only thing you need to do is to provide a DDL file, execute the DatabaseCreator to create the database, and enter data into the predefined data set XML file. In addition to that it also provides some nice utility methods and classes such as RowComparator and getEnhancedTester() and it overrides the default DbUnit setting to use fully qualified table names (in the form schema.table).

How to use

Follow the 6 easy steps at the homepage. Summary:
  1. Add the necessary dependencies to your project (see the web page or the embedded pom.xml)
  2. Create the folder testData/ under your project's root folder.
  3. (optional) Prepare .ddl: Copy DbUnitTestSkeleton/testData/create_db_content.ddl into the new testData/ and modify it to fit your data schema needs.
  4. (optional) Create&Initialize DB: Run DatabaseCreator#main from your project's root folder to create and initialize the test DB from the .ddl file.
  5. Write a TestCase either using EmbeddedDbTester or subclassing the AbstractEmbeddedDbTestCase and implement your tests there. (See SimpleEmbeddedDbTest.java for inspiration.) You may want to override its getDataSet() if you want to use st. else than testData/dbunit-test_data_set.xml.
  6. Prepare test data: Copy DbUnitTestSkeleton/testData/dbunit-test_data_set.xml into your new testData/ and modify it to fit your data needs. Any table mentioned in the file will be emptied prior to running test, if it has any rows defined then those will be also inserted.
  7. Run the test.

Example of usage

See the SimpleEmbeddedDbTest.java which is a part of this project to see a complete example.

Verify data in DB


 // Inside a test class ...

 private EmbeddedDbTester testDb = new EmbeddedDbTester();

 public void setUp() {
        testDb.onSetup();
 }

 public void tearDown() {
        testDb.onTearDown();
 }

 public void testMyMethodXY() {
        // ...
        // after invoking the method under test:
        ITable rowsToInsertTbl = testDb.getConnection().createQueryTable("rowToInsert", "SELECT MY_EXAMPLE_COLUMN FROM ... WHERE ...");
        assertEquals("There shall be exactly 1 row for the given id.", 1, rowsToInsertTbl.getRowCount());
        String dbVal = (String) rowsToInsertTbl.getValue(0, "MY_EXAMPLE_COLUMN");
  assertEquals("Value expected in the MY_EXAMPLE_COLUMN", "hello", dbVal);
        }

Custom configuration and customizations

By default we use an embedded Derby database stored at a specific location as defined by this class' constants. You may change the driver, database etc. by providing a configuration of your own in a properties file, see CUSTOM_CONFIG_FILE.

You may also change what data set is used for initializing the database by either overriding createDefaultDataSet() or setting the desired data set with setDataSet(IDataSet). See DbUnit_Test_Skeleton subproject of jeeutils at SourceForge

Since:
1.1.0

jholy

public static final String SVN_ID
File's Subversion info (version etc.). It's replacement upon commit must be enabled in svn properties.

Constant Field Values

TEST_DATA_FOLDER

public static final String TEST_DATA_FOLDER
Name of the folder storing our test data set XML, DB initialization DDL and the Derby db itself.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

DBUNIT_TEST_DATA_SET_NAME

public static final String DBUNIT_TEST_DATA_SET_NAME
Name of our test data set XML file loaded by default into the database by this class unless overridden by a subclass. The file should be stored in the folder TEST_DATA_FOLDER.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

CUSTOM_CONFIG_FILE

public static final String CUSTOM_CONFIG_FILE
An optional file for defining other then the default connection to a test database, it may include any of the following properties:
  • PropertiesBasedJdbcDatabaseTester.DBUNIT_CONNECTION_URL
  • PropertiesBasedJdbcDatabaseTester.DBUNIT_DRIVER_CLASS
  • PropertiesBasedJdbcDatabaseTester.DBUNIT_PASSWORD
  • PropertiesBasedJdbcDatabaseTester.DBUNIT_USERNAME
If a property isn't defined in the file then the value of the appropriate DEFAULT_JDBC_* constant is taken.

See Also:
Constant Field Values
Constructor Detail

EmbeddedDbTester

public EmbeddedDbTester()
Create a new embedded DB tester ready to use, optionally configured by properties defined in the file "dbunit-express.properties" if it's somewhere on the classpath.

Do not forget to call its onSetup() before using it in a test to modify or read the test database.

EmbeddedDbTester

public EmbeddedDbTester(String xmlFileName)
                 throws org.dbunit.DatabaseUnitRuntimeException
Create a new embedded DB tester ready to use with a non-standard data set file, optionally configured by properties defined in the file "dbunit-express.properties" if it's somewhere on the classpath.

Do not forget to call its onSetup() before using it in a test to modify or read the test database.

Parameters:
xmlFileName - (required) a XML file defining DbUnit data set either in the testData folder or anywhere on the classpath
Throws:
org.dbunit.DatabaseUnitRuntimeException
See Also:
setDataSet(String)
Method Detail

setConnectionProperty

protected final String setConnectionProperty(String key,
                                             String value)
This method let you set or override any of the connection properties, which are normally loaded from the CUSTOM_CONFIG_FILE if it exists. A property set in this file or via this method has a higher priority than the default values. See the custom config file's JavaDoc to learn about the possible properties.

Beware that changing the properties has any effect on a database tester only before it is created. Via createAndInitDatabaseTester() you will always get a new one based on the current values of all the properties but getWrappedTester() only initializes its tester during the furst invocation.

To be used only for very special cases, such as in the DatabaseCreator.

Parameters:
key - (required)
value - (required)
Returns:
the previous value for that key or null

resolveConnectionProperty

protected final String resolveConnectionProperty(String key)
                                          throws IllegalArgumentException
Returns the value of the given connection property that would be used when creating a new database tester via createAndInitDatabaseTester(). Based on the loaded/set connection properties and the default values.

Parameters:
key - (required) see the JavaDoc of CUSTOM_CONFIG_FILE for possible values
Returns:
the property's value (normally should never be null)
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - IF there is no such connection property
See Also:
setConnectionProperty(String, String)

createAndInitDatabaseTester

protected final IEnhancedDatabaseTester createAndInitDatabaseTester()
Create the internally used database tester, which supports fully qualified table names and uses an embedded Derby database.

We also set the system properties that define the test DB connection based on the getCustomJdbc* methods or the DEFAULT_JDBC_* constants like DEFAULT_JDBC_URL if the methods return null.

getWrappedTester

protected final IEnhancedDatabaseTester getWrappedTester()
Get the internally used tester implementation instance, if it is not set yet it will be created first.

See Also:
createAndInitDatabaseTester()

setWrappedTester

protected final void setWrappedTester(IEnhancedDatabaseTester actualTester)
With this method a subclass may replace the internally used wrapper by calling it e.g. in the constructor.

getEnhancedTester

public IEnhancedDatabaseTester getEnhancedTester()
Returns an enhanced manager of the test database that provides additional utility methods, for example for replacing its data.

createDefaultDataSet

protected org.dbunit.dataset.IDataSet createDefaultDataSet()
                                                    throws org.dbunit.DatabaseUnitRuntimeException,
                                                           org.dbunit.dataset.DataSetException
Create the default data set used to fill the test DB by reading the default XML "dbunit-test_data_set.xml". Used if no custom data set is provided via setDataSet(IDataSet). Override if you want to load data from a different file(s) or if you prefer a different format of the data sat (e.g. FlatXmlDataSet).

Throws:
org.dbunit.DatabaseUnitRuntimeException
org.dbunit.dataset.DataSetException

onSetup

public void onSetup()
             throws Exception
Initiate the database by clearing tables and filling them with data from the data set. Only tables that are mentioned in the data set are cleared of data.

Under JUnit 4 you may prefer to use EmbeddedDbTesterRule instead of this class because it calls onSetup automatically, see the example in its JavaDoc.

The default set up operation and test data sets are used unless you they have been changed via their setters (only rarely needed)

We've added some better error reporting in the case that the test DB hasn't been created yet.

Specified by:
onSetup in interface org.dbunit.IDatabaseTester
Throws:
Exception
See Also:
DatabaseTestCase.setUp()

onTearDown

public void onTearDown()
                throws Exception
As of now this method doesn't do anything and so you can ignore it.

Specified by:
onTearDown in interface org.dbunit.IDatabaseTester
Throws:
Exception

setDataSet

public final void setDataSet(org.dbunit.dataset.IDataSet testDataSet)
If you do not want the default test data set to be used (read from "testData"/"dbunit-test_data_set.xml") but prefer some other one, you can set it via this method.

Specified by:
setDataSet in interface org.dbunit.IDatabaseTester
Parameters:
testDataSet - the data to insert into the DB before each test
See Also:
IDatabaseTester.setDataSet(IDataSet)

setDataSet

public final void setDataSet(String xmlFileName)
                      throws org.dbunit.DatabaseUnitRuntimeException
If you do not want the default test data set to be used (read from "testData"/"dbunit-test_data_set.xml") but prefer some other one, you can set it via this method.

It is a good practice - if you plan multiple tests - to have a separate data set for each, co-located with the test class. So for MyTest you would have e.g. MyTest-data.xml in the same folder and call testDb.setDataSet("MyTest-data.xml"); It may be a good idea to create a parent test class that automatically calls setDataSet(getClass().getName() + "-data.xml");

Parameters:
xmlFileName - (required) a XML file defining DbUnit data set either in the testData folder or anywhere on the classpath
Throws:
org.dbunit.dataset.DataSetException
org.dbunit.DatabaseUnitRuntimeException

setSchema

public void setSchema(String schema)
               throws UnsupportedOperationException
This method is meaningless for this particular tester and thus throws an exception. Notice that if necessary you may still use unqualified names, which will then use the default schema for the test DB (SA for Derby).

Specified by:
setSchema in interface org.dbunit.IDatabaseTester
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - This tester requires table names to be always fully qualified (i.e. schema.table) and thus setting a schema has no effect and shouldn't be used.
See Also:
IDatabaseTester.setSchema(java.lang.String)
